children.text: As a cryptocurrency magnate who once effectively admitted he‚Äôs in the "Ponzi business" goes bust, we take a look at how he got chummy with the Washington establishment to shield his company from regulatory scrutiny ‚Äî and the implications of such a shaky scheme for the ordinary investors who lost their savings. Andrew Perez, Rebecca Burns, and Matthew Cunningham-Cook do a deeper dive in
A FRIEND OF THE LEVER‚ÄôS ELECTION OP-ED:
co-host Krystal Ball wrote a column for

about the victories Dems notched across the industrial Midwest during election week. As she put it, ‚ÄúAfter decades of corporatists in both major parties kicking these voters in the face, the Biden administration actually did a few decent things for the region. And it turns out, when you do decent things for people, they tend to vote for you.‚Äù Check out the entire op-ed

children.html: Spread the word: Forward this email to encourage others to subscribe to The Lever.

children.text: In April, when cryptocurrency guru and Democratic mega-donor Sam Bankman-Fried described how crypto tokens work on a

, the host remarked that it sounded a lot like being ‚Äúin the Ponzi business.‚Äù Bankman-Fried, founder of the FTX cryptocurrency exchange, replied that this was ‚Äúa pretty reasonable response‚Äù with a ‚Äúdepressing amount of validity.‚Äù
The conversation ‚Äî which occurred days after one of the industry‚Äôs top regulators in Washington
a picture with Bankman-Fried ‚Äî probably should have set off blaring alarm bells throughout Washington, D.C., and the financial industry. It didn‚Äôt.
On Friday, FTX, which previously had $16 billion in customer assets, and was valued at
in its most recent investor funding round in September,
for bankruptcy in Delaware. Bankman-Fried, 30, resigned as its CEO.
The collapse underscores how the $849-billion crypto industry ‚Äî down by
in the last week and from a high of
a year ago ‚Äî has been protected by regulators who are asleep at the wheel, while hapless ordinary investors, suckered in with slick ads from prominent
after Bankman-Fried‚Äôs prescient comments on the

in the Bahamas with world leaders, celebrities, and investors. On stage, Bankman-Fried interviewed former President Bill Clinton and former British Prime Minister Tony Blair while wearing a T-shirt, shorts, and New Balance sneakers.
, Clinton suggested that regulators should adopt a ‚Äòdo no harm‚Äô mentality when dealing with cryptocurrencies.

At the time, Bankman-Fried was fashioning himself as a political kingmaker, boosting crypto-friendly candidates in a series of Democratic congressional primaries, and getting advice from veteran Democratic consultants and younger, quasi-left upstarts. In May, Bankman-Fried
he aimed to spend up to $1 billion on the 2024 elections.
Now, just six months later, FTX has fully collapsed. According to the
, FTX had ‚Äúlent billions of dollars worth of customer assets to fund risky bets by its affiliated trading firm, Alameda Research, setting the stage for the exchange‚Äôs implosion.‚Äù

The downfall was swift: When Binance, a competitor crypto exchange, announced on November 6 it was unloading its holdings of digital tokens issued by FTX and in which Alameda was heavily invested, customers
from the tokens and FTX. Bankman-Fried announced on November 8 that Binance was acquiring FTX, pending due diligence, before Binance pulled out of the deal. Soon, FTX was out of money.

of a new regulatory push around crypto, though larger questions still remain: How have regulators allowed the crypto industry to operate with so little scrutiny for so long? Why did the political and consulting class accept and even court Bankman-Fried‚Äôs intrusion into Democratic Party politics, even after he effectively admitted the scam?
From A Complete Unknown To Political Player

Bankman-Fried, the scion of tenured Stanford Law Professors, entered the crypto space in 2017 with the founding of his firm Alameda Research. His initial trades focused on exploiting the price difference between Bitcoin in the U.S. and in Japan.
. Bitcoin is the most successful and best-known crypto, but there are thousands of others. One in five American adults own some form of crypto,
Bankman-Fried, who was at one time
, made his presence known in the political world in 2020 when he donated $5 million to a super PAC supporting Joe Biden‚Äôs presidential campaign. That donation earned him a fluffy
magazine headlined, ‚ÄúThe Mysterious Cryptocurrency Magnate Who Became One of Biden‚Äôs Biggest Donors.‚Äù
This year, Bankman-Fried spent millions trying to decide Democratic congressional primaries and donated thousands to Democratic lawmakers overseeing the crypto industry.

Bankman-Fried began by bankrolling a super PAC, called Protect Our Future, that intervened in Democratic primaries. While the group‚Äôs $10 million ad blitz designed to crown a virtually unknown candidate, Carrick Flynn, in an Oregon primary failed, its other spending was highly effective.

Protect our Future spent $1 million to help reelect Rep. Shontel Brown (D-Ohio), who was facing a competitive primary challenge from progressive Nina Turner. Brown has key committee assignments: She sits on both the House Agriculture Committee ‚Äî which oversees the Commodities Future Trading Commission, one of the primary regulators for the crypto industry ‚Äî and the Oversight
on Economic and Consumer Policy, whose chair is investigating crypto.
Democratic Rep. Lucy McBath successfully navigate a competitive Georgia primary and aided the primary campaign of Florida progressive candidate Maxwell Frost, who just won election.

children.text: Along the way, Bankman-Fried developed ties with heavy hitters in the Democratic consulting world, as well as younger, party-aligned operatives who are generally perceived as progressive but spend much of their time attacking left-wing policy proposals
Sean McElwee, the founding executive director of the polling outfit Data for Progress, has reportedly
from Protect Our Future in June. Bankman-Fried, McElwee, and data bro David Shor jointly hosted a fundraiser for Rep. Ritchie Torres (D-N.Y.) this spring, according to

for Protect Our Future this election cycle include: former Hillary Clinton campaign spokesperson Jesse Ferguson; Global Strategy Group, which works with official Democratic Party committees; and the polling firm Mellman Group, whose president
leads a pro-Israel super PAC dedicated to crushing progressives in primaries.
Rep. Sean Casten, a Democrat from Illinois, employed Bankman-Fried‚Äôs brother and consigliere Gabe as an

from 2019 to 2021. Casten later became a member of the ‚ÄúDigital Assets Working Group‚Äù of Democrats on the House Financial Services Committee, which was focused on crypto. Casten did not immediately respond to a request for comment from
Crypto Tries To Pick Its Regulator
As Bankman-Fried attempted to flex his muscles in the electoral arena, he also became a regular presence on Capitol Hill, ostensibly helping lead the charge for regulation of his nascent industry.
a crypto lobbying group called the Association for Digital Asset Market (ADAM), which pushed to
the aggressive new leadership of the Securities and Exchange Commission. Using
a bill pushed by Sen. Kirsten Gillibrand (D-N.Y.) and Cynthia Lummis (R-Wyo.)
, ADAM instead tried to position the far-smaller and more poorly-funded Commodities Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) as its exclusive regulator.
a statement from ADAM on her website promoting the legislation. That webpage has since been deleted. ADAM‚Äôs own website
FTX general counsel Ryne Miller as part of the organization‚Äôs board of directors; his name has now been
Bankman-Fried combined his behind-the-scenes lobbying ‚Äî both through ADAM and his own firm, which
$670,000 lobbying this year ‚Äî with a public-facing critique about how crypto really needs to be regulated.
‚Äú[The U.S. should] be able to strike a balance between fostering economic growth and providing consumer protection and protecting against systemic risk and financial crimes,‚Äù
in a February interview with the Economic Club of New York.
Bankman-Fried‚Äôs remarks to New York‚Äôs elites came as SEC Chairman Gary Gensler began taking a tougher posture towards crypto. Gensler warned
that most trading platforms would need to register with the agency, and that the SEC was
of its special unit policing crypto.

As such, the industry began seeking to shunt regulatory supervision to the CFTC. A relatively marginal agency originally tasked with overseeing agricultural futures contracts, the CFTC has neither the resources nor the mandate of the SEC.
The fact that the CFTC was handed oversight, in the wake of the 2008 financial crisis, of the sprawling U.S. derivatives market
is already referred to by advocates
as the ‚ÄúAchilles heel‚Äù of Dodd-Frank financial reform.
In November 2021, FTX kicked off a full-court press to pick its preferred regulator by
hiring former CFTC commissioner Mark Wetjen
as its head of ‚Äúpolicy and regulation.‚Äù FTX‚Äôs general counsel, Miller, is a
Bankman-Fried discussed his push for crypto regulatory clarity in the same April podcast where he suggested that the crypto tokens traded on his platform are effectively a Ponzi scheme.

columnist Matt Levine that ‚Äúthe thing that makes me the [most] bullish about crypto asset pricing is just the amount of money that isn‚Äôt able to access it today.‚Äù Bankman-Fried was referring to the broad market of banks, mutual funds, and pension funds known as institutional investors that have resisted major investments in crypto, likely due to regulatory concerns. The world‚Äôs largest pension funds have
in assets, and mutual funds have

Reflecting on his desired policy outcomes, Bankman-Fried said, ‚ÄúWe need to know what regulatory framework we are a part of, what licenses are necessary to play different roles in this space‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs roughly where the money gets trapped.‚Äù
The following month, the House Agriculture Committee ‚Äî which retains jurisdiction over the CFTC, thanks to the historical quirk of its origins ‚Äî held a hearing on a
allowing investors to use borrowed money
for a new form of round-the-clock crypto trading.

The plan, which would have cut brokers and other third-parties out of the trading process, drew condemnation from House Agriculture Committee Chair David Scott (D-Ga.), who called it ‚Äúa serious threat‚Äù to global derivatives markets.

But it drew tacit praise from members like Democratic Congressional Committee Chair Sean Patrick Maloney (D-N.Y.), who gushed, ‚ÄúI have to tell you, Mr. Bankman-Fried, I am fascinated by this, and I think this is a really interesting idea. You sure got everybody stirred up, and they hate it. They hate this idea.‚Äù
to Maloney this cycle. In September, Maloney
introduced a more tailored version of Gillibrand‚Äôs bill
to hand regulatory authority of crypto over to the CFTC.
A companion bill in the Senate was
The fate of those bills is now unclear. Both the SEC and the CFTC
into FTX this week. The agencies could have launched investigations into FTX‚Äôs liquidity far earlier, but failed to do so.
It is unclear when, if ever, FTX customers will be able to recover any of their assets.
on Friday that he is ‚Äúgoing to work on giving clarity on where things are in terms of user recovery ASAP.‚ÄùLate Friday, FTX
that it had been hacked. The company wrote: ‚ÄúFTX apps are malware. Delete them. Chat is open. Don't go on FTX site as it might download Trojans.‚Äù
